unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: College Football Coach
question_text:
A college football coach has had a dismal year.
The alumni association queries members of the alumni club. Of an SRS of $100\text{ members}$, $64$ of them are in favor of firing the coach.
Compute a $95\%$ confidence interval for the true proportion of alumni who favor firing the coach.
solution:
Use your calculator for a one-proportion confidence interval, with $X = 64$, $n = 100$, and a CI of $0.95$.

You get a CI $(95)$ of $(0.54592, 0.73408)$.

Since the point estimate for p is $0.64$, it is in the middle of the interval. Subtract $0.64$ from $0.7348$ to get the margin of error, which is $0.09408$. That rounds to $0.094$.

An alternate way is to use the formula for a confidence interval for a population proportion:

$$p \pm z \sqrt{\dfrac{p(1-p)}{n}}$$

Substituting $0.64$ for $p$, $100$ for $n$, and $1.96$ for $z$ yields $0.64\pm(1.96)(0.048)$.

Thus, the confidence interval becomes $0.64\pm0.09408$, which again rounds to $0.64\pm0.094$.

Therefore, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.
